content: I hate to start a new Zulip topic, but I couldn't find an existing topic that seems relevant to something I'm getting increasing concerned about: Config Management. In a nutshell, I think it's too hard to use, and a huge barrier to entry for new users. I think it needs to be friendlier for Backdrop to succeed.

I'm happy to add to this later, but I'm in the midst of heavy work on my current main commitment, so I just want to add this as a bookmark to come back to later (though I'm happy to join in on any conversations it sparks.)
I was reminded about it when I hit this dialog while mucking around with one of my backdrop installs:
image.png
If I was a new user who didn't yet feel committed to a system, a message like that would make me want to find a different platform.

One possibility: perhaps we can guide them better on how to fix it? Can't we look around and try to find existing config files? (which in my case are there somewhere.) I realize there are big security concerns -- we don't want to make it too easy for an attacker to switch around config settings! -- but within the bounds of safety I feel like we can get closer than this.

(How did I get this message? I discovered that doing "git reset --hard" on a live site is not a good idea! Fortunately the site I FUBARed was a test installation with no meaningful content, and I was able to bring it back by renaming my existing config folder to the name Backdrop was looking for in the above message.)
Whoops...maybe I spoke too soon about having successfully brought it back: image.png
(Fixed it -- it was a permissions issue. But...for a new user, a "permissions issue" is likely unsolvable.)

One of my pet peeves (maybe the only one, but certainly the biggest) is the lack of adequate error checking and reporting done in Drupal (and by extension, Backdrop).

I suspect you are correct with the first error, but for the second one, more error checking and reporting could certainly be done there.

The code doesn't do any basic file checks at all, and the call to file_put_contents() actually hides the actual error (with the "@" in the 6th line below) that would be recorded in watchdog, making that code not only insufficient, but also less than helpful by removing any information that could be used to fix the problem.

  public function write($name, array $data) {
    // Ensure that the config name is included in the written file.
    $data = array_merge(array('_config_name' => $name), $data);
    $data = $this->encode($data) . "\n";
    $file_path = $this->getFilePath($name);
    $status = @file_put_contents($file_path, $data);
    if ($status === FALSE) {
      throw new ConfigStorageException('Failed to write configuration file: ' . $this->getFilePath($name));
    }
    clearstatcache(FALSE, $file_path);
    return TRUE;
  }

I don't know if adding that would help a new user, but I suspect if someone is getting a file permission error, it is because they put the files there, and didn't use a one-click type of install process, so they should know how to fix it with an adequete error message.

@Luke McCormick that error you got is being discussed over at https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/4747 and was brought up recently.

empty configuration directory when attempting docker install · Issue #4747 · backdrop/backdrop-issues
When I attempt to start a docker instance of backdrop, I get an error similar to the following: Exception: The configuration directory in settings.php is specified as './files/config_a1614e8130...

...there's also https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/2263 which is related.

Ignore README.md when checking if active config directory is empty on install · Issue #2263 · backdrop/backdrop-issues
When reinstalling my site, I'm getting an error that the active config directory must be empty: The directory ./config/active must be completely empty to proceed with installation. However, the...

I believe that there are various use cases that could cause this error, and we could do a better job at catching those. This error seems to be coming up when people try to destroy their local and start from scratch ...we could be catching these cases and throwing more user-friendly errors there ...possibly with links to documentation.

I believe #4747 is about something different.

empty configuration directory when attempting docker install · Issue #4747 · backdrop/backdrop-issues
When I attempt to start a docker instance of backdrop, I get an error similar to the following: Exception: The configuration directory in settings.php is specified as './files/config_a1614e8130...

I believe that it's the same problem manifesting itself under different conditions (when spinning up docer-based instances) ...still has to do with Backdrop not being able to properly detect the config directory ...or not properly detect if it's empty or not ...or there is a config directory, but it doesn't match what's in settings.php.
@oadaeh (Jason Flatt) I believe PHP 7.? or 8 will fix the problem with hiding errors with "@" by removing it.

Just got off a call with a long time Drupal friend who is in the process of moving a number of simple D6 and D7 sites to Backdrop. He frequently tells me how much he likes Backdrop, but tonight had some pretty harsh things to say about his frustration with config management.
I think he said something about "taking us back to the stone age" at one point. ;-)
Knowing you @StPaulTim I assume you've taken notes re their pain points.
Well, mostly he was referring to problems that are well known to me already.
@StPaulTim like what...? I currently write a longer article about Backdrop and my intention is to mention Config pretty often;-)
@StPaulTim I'm curious: what's so "stone-agy" about config management with exportable json files? I find it pretty lean and handy. What were the core issues for your friend re config?

I share his pain. Either we need to find a way to make it easier to use, or we need to create documentation that explains how it already is easier. (Or I have to find and read that documentation, if it already exists)

I'm curious: what's so "stone-agy" about config management with exportable json files?

I think the point that he was making was in terms of workflows. He is big on dev-opsy stuff and likes to automate his workflow and uses drush pretty extenstively.

I think his frustrations were very much around the lack of tools and/or documentation about how to use tools to effectively manage config files.
Are there any drush/brush commands that help with config?

We discussed the fact unless you commit your config files everytime to you make a change, they are vulnerable. One can use backup and migrate to take daily snapshots of the database and files, but any changes in conifg are not backed up anywhere if something happens to your active config directory and its not clear to me that we have any good tools right now to help secure config files.
@StPaulTim he sounds competent enough to help write some drush tools. I think there's a drush command for exporting
And importing

Yup :+1: ...there's config-related commands for (the Backdrop flavor of) drush: https://github.com/backdrop-contrib/backdrop-drush-extension/tree/1.x-1.x/commands/config ...the same as the respective drush commands in D8 AFAICT.

Happy New Year, Config thread. I'm starting the new year wrestling with config.

So...I'm trying to make a local copy of a site (my home page) using what I think is almost the most vanilla possible approach: I'm using GUI interface, no drush/git/command line involved in the config management. Does anybody actually do this?
I haven't, but I believe its possible by exporting and importing config via the UI... What's the issue?

I've cloned a new backdrop site, copied my themes, modules, and files folders into place, and used backup_and_migrate to restore the DB. That all worked, and I see my content, but the stuff that's in config (notably views) isn't there; I need config.

On my source site, I do a full export, then on the destination site I do a full import. I get "Your configuration files were successfully uploaded" and I see 31 configurations changed and 28 new configurations ready to import, 2 removed. When I say "import all" I get "Configuration sync failed. The following errors were reported:
The field "field_pos" could not be created because a database table with the name "field_data_field_pos" already exists."

Probably relevant: I hadn't updated the DB. When I tried to, I got some errors. Ultimately, 9 updates failed, with messages like this:

Update #1016
Failed: DatabaseSchemaObjectExistsException: Table cache_entity_user already exists. in DatabaseSchema->createTable() (line 661 of /var/www/html/core/includes/database/schema.inc).

@Luke McCormick (cellear) - I won't say that what you are doing is impossible. But, I run into problems like what you are experiencing and get around it by placing the config directly into the active directory.

Using the GUI to move config into a new site is problematic. I need to better understand when using the GUI works and when it doesn't.
But, I know that it sometimes doesn't work in situations where I really expect it will.

Hmm, we should probably be checking if the database tables already exist and just moving on if they do. Importing a config file for a field that already exists should not cause problems like that for users.

I agree with @Joseph Flatt ... @Luke McCormick (cellear) if you have the time/energy, and you can reproduce this consistently on a vanilla Backdrop setup, with minimal steps, then I'd file an issue for it.

...having said that, some of the errors you are getting seem to be related to (or the same as) https://www.drupal.org/node/1551132 ...which is set to be backported to D7, and for which we already have an issue in our queue: https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/2585

DatabaseSchemaObjectExistsException: Table already exists in DatabaseSchema · Issue #2585 · backdrop/backdrop-issues
I was hit by this in a D7 site. I think we should fix it in Backdrop so that people don't scratch their heads over things like this. This also falls under the "make contrib devs' life ...

@Luke McCormick (cellear) wondering if you could try the patch from https://www.drupal.org/files/issues/2020-07-02/1551132-113.patch and see if that solves the last problem you mention re updates not being able to run.
...or if you can share the db and config files with me, then I can do the testing :smile:
If you're just cloning a site you don't need to import via the UI. Can just copy files from active to active folders.
How would I (or more importantly, a new user) know to do that? I was following the instructions in the interface.
This really sounded like what I wanted to do: image.png
We are sprinting today. It's a great day to get some help text suggestions into Github and maybe we can create a PR.

Can I suggest that some of you who are more technically gifted, not be so? By that I mean, do as might many D7 web admins do, and work off the GUI/front end, without using drush, or other tools.
I suggest as much to highlight the issues that arise, for example, when trying to import a config from a local server instance.
E.g. I had repeated errors of one module breaking the import synchronization -- it was the footnotes module. I had it enabled. Still failing. I eventually enabled all sections -- footnotes in views, Footnotes Wysiwyg, and footnotes blocks. Even though my local instances on my local server did not have those enabled.
There were other examples. Eventually I gave up, and just copied the local server active json files into the production active directory. But I'm not sufficiently technical to know what errors that might induce down the track.
I'm concerned that many D7 admins who aren't all that technical - when encountering such difficulties -- will reconsider BD, and instead move to WP.
In business circles, there is a saying - the number one rule is "make it easy for the customer". If you make it hard, many will not complain, they'll just move away (to WP).
I understand that a major focus of the BD team, is to make it easy to use Backdrop, like WP. Hence my suggestion , to make like a non-technical D7 admin, to 'flesh out' the road-blocks.

@SteveP what I think should happen is that if you notice this being a pattern (that is similar message, for multiple config files, for various contrib modules), then please take notes/screenshots, and raise a ticket with core. If after investigation it turns out that:

  • it is because of something on the contrib end (modules not properly ported, or their uninstall hooks not cleaning up config files), then we can individually fix that on each contrib module

I have a crazy thought about config management.

CMI was intended to make some things easier. Because configuration is stored in the file system instead the database, it's easier to do things that were difficult to do when configuration was stored in the database --- notably, track configuration changes in a VCS.

The downside is, it makes some things harder. If you're doing something that involves moving the database then CMI just means that there is an additional piece to worry about. And that piece is somewhat brittle and finicky, as discussed above.

So...what if we did both? Let configuration be stored not just in files, but also (perhaps optionally) in the database? It could be super simple, just a table with two fields, for the title and the contents of each config file. One row for each file.

That way, if you move the database, you don't have to move the config files. You could use Backup&Migrate unmodified, for example. It could be just a third config source -- Active, Staging, and DB.

Would anybody besides me find this appealing?

I believe https://github.com/silkscreencms/silkscreen already has something like that. Though I'm having a hard time finding references to it. Maybe @John Franklin can confirm.

Side note: If you go to the Silkscreen website (rather than the GitHub repo), there's no link or info about where/how to download it... @John Franklin
@oadaeh (Jason Flatt) you're correct. I recall the issue where the CMI was abstracted a bit so this was possible
@Luke McCormick (cellear) , yes Silkscreen does support configuration stored in the database, and what you said is one of the primary reasons why.

In addition, there is a memory-backed storage configuration driver (https://github.com/silkscreencms-contrib/config_memory) that is useful for storing overrides from settings.local.php.

Memory-based configuration storage driver. Contribute to silkscreencms-contrib/config_memory development by creating an account on GitHub.

The README.md in the Layered Configuration driver explains how to set up the memory + database to provide overrides. https://github.com/silkscreencms-contrib/config_layered

Layered configuration storage driver. Contribute to silkscreencms-contrib/config_layered development by creating an account on GitHub.
